bioghist.p: John W. Harshberger (1869-1929) was a Philadelphia botanist, biographer, historian and professor of botany at the University of Pennsylvania. He received his Ph.D. from the University of Pennsylvania in 1893, after which he made an extensive scientific tour of Europe, South America, Mexico, and the United States, collecting specimens as he went. He was the author of more than a dozen books and more than 320 papers on botanical subjects. His book Botanists of Philadelphia and Their Works portrays a history of American botany along with the biographies.

scopecontent.p: This is a set of 12 volumes of Illustrations of North American Vegetation, companion volumes to a phytographic Survey of North America (Die Vegetation der Erde); one volume of Illustrations of Foreign Vegetation; and an extra-illustration volume of Vegetation of South Florida (Transactions, Wagner Free Institute of Science, vol VII pt.3, Oct 1914). The volumes illustrate the vegetation and geology of various regions of the United States, Mexico, and the Caribbean, with a small selection of images of vegetation from around the world. Pasted into the volumes are photographs, postcards, images clipped from journals, pamphlets, and magazines, letters, and maps. Photographers whose images are used in the volumes include Harshberger, Henry Troth, and William Rau. The collection also includes a copy of Harshberger's The Vegetation of the New Jersey Pine Barrens, 1916, inscribed by the author.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
